document_data.name: Kymil Nimesin
document_data.mainbody: '''Kymil Nimesin''' was a [[sun elf]] who had earned a spotless reputation as one of the finest teachers of swordsmanship and as an eminent person at the [[Elven Court]].
document_data.Relationships:
Kymil was a member of the [[Nimesin]] clan, which was a minor branch of the [[Durothil]] clan, one of the oldest and most honored houses.
He loved [[Filaura Ni'Tessine]], one of his [[Elite Guard]] and [[Circle Singers]] but she was killed by Arilyn
document_data.History:
Kymil was over 600 years old by [[1369 DR]] and had borne witness to the fall of [[Myth Drannor]] and the rise of the [[House Moonflower]] rulers of [[Evermeet]]. The latter event he regarded as an abomination that never should have happened, considering the sun elves to be the true rulers of [[elf|elvenkind]]. He had spent much of his life toiling endlessly to come up with a plan to kill off the royal family of Evermeet and restore the [[Council of Elders]], which was the form of government in the days of Myth Drannor. Towards this end, he employed numerous agents and resources, including a group of gold elves he referred to as his Elite Guard, treasure taken from a [[dragon|dragon's]] hoard and even the [[dark elven]] goddess [[Lolth]].

His efforts had almost succeeded, and all members of the royal family but three were dead, including [[Zaor Moonflower|King Zaor Moonflower]] and [[Amnestria|Princess Amnestria]], the mother of [[Arilyn Moonblade]]. However, Arilyn and [[Danilo Thann]] managed to relocate the portal to Evermeet he planned to use, and she defeated him in hand-to-hand combat. He was tried by a [[Harper]] tribunal and sentenced to lifelong imprisonment in some remote dimensional plane, but escaped with the aid of Lolth and renewed his plan by mounting a massive assault upon Evermeet that left many elves dead. He was again stopped, this time by [[Lamruil Moonflower|Prince Lamruil]], but again escaped through use of a magical ring.

Kymil's whereabouts afterwards were unknown, but he was believed to be pursuing the same goal, which he had come to believe in so fanatically that there were many who questioned his sanity.
